729589f-a.title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hamilton Avenue
729589f-a.text:
St. Marks hlace, east side, between Hami ton Avenue and Nicholas Street, showing thhe sumptuous Castleton Potel. It was built in 189 on the site of the old t. Sarks Hotel and the 'Marhle House" of Gilbert L. Thompson, son-in-law of Governor Tompkins. The Potel was burned Novemer 12, 1907.
Ahout 1905
By Mulford Simonson
From Staten Asland Museum Collection through P. L. Sperr
729589f-a.folder: St. Marks Place & Hamilton Avenue, Staten Island, NY

729590f-a.title: Richmond: St. Marks Place - Hamilton Avenue
729590f-a.text:
St. Marks Place, north from Hamilton Avenue to Nicholas Street, showing urtis High School (left) and Cstleton Park,exclusive residential development, occupying the former site of the famous Castleton Hotel. The white 7-story building is the Castieton apamtments,. at the S.E. corner of Nicholas Street. Beyond that (at the N.E. corner)
is the Wisteria Anartmerts.
May 2, 1928
P. L. Sperr
729590f-a.folder: St. Marks Place & Hamilton Avenue, Staten Island, NY

728905f-b.title: Richmond: Hamilton Avenue - St. Marks Place
728905f-b.text:
Hamilton Avenue, at its western intersection with St. Marks Place, showing Curtis High School. The two wings were not part of the original school building, but were added on years later.
Views 1,21 May 2, 1928
View 3: June 22, 1937
P. L. Sperr
728905f-b.folder: Hamilton Avenue & St. Marks Place, Staten Island, NY

Hamilton Avenue, at its western intersection with St. Marks Place, showing Curtis High School.

additions to the high school.
